title: How to prove that a problem is undecidable - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not easy. Kurt Godel’s Incompleteness Theorem is available in an a book that was not terribly expensive at least 40 yeas ago. It is not easy to understand, in part because the logic of Godel’s theorem is conceptually not simple, but also because the book is not pedagogical. I tried it and failed. Maybe there is a more instructive presentation somewhere. But a summary or such is in my opinion not of much value except to give one the idea that any Computer “Science” dude who imagines he or she can do everything is missing the point and needs to submit his or her ideation to scrutiny by persons who re not just clever but also empathic and wise. On the other hand, I once had a manager who said: We the unwilling, led by the unknowing, have done so much with so little for so long that now we are qualified to do everything with nothing. He was a very good manager and such a master computer programmer that he told the manufacturer’s (Burroughs mid-range computers) representatives what the problems were with their operating software and how to fix them.

No problem is undecidable in the Old Testament the high priest placed a white and black stone of equal size called the Turim and the Urim inside his Brestplate. He then prayed about the Problem moving the two stones about in the breastplate after coming to a Decision He removed one Stone. If the stone was white it represented Yes so he went ahead with the Decision. If Black it represented No He left things as they were. Place all your trust in God and it will work every time
